title: Apple's Headset has M1??
description: Check out NZXT's BLD system today at:    LISTEN TO THE TECH NEWS:  GET MERCH:  SUPPORT US ON FLOATPLANE:    LTX EXPO:      NEWS SOURCES:  --------------------------------------------------- Timestamps: 0:00 LEAVE TECH NEWS ALONE 0:07 Apple AR headset with 'Mac' power 1:08 Italy fines Big Tech 2:09 NASA DART mission 3:17 NZXT BLD 3:58 QUICK BITS 4:05 DLSS works in Linux via Proton 4:34 UK to ban default passwords 5:04 Nvidia Canvas AI  5:41 Xbox pauses FPS Boost development 6:16 Renault Air4   AFFILIATES & REFERRALS --------------------------------------------------- Affiliates, Sponsors & Referrals:  Private Internet Access VPN:  MK Keyboards:  Nerd or Die Stream Overlays:  Official Game Store:  Amazon Prime:  Audible Free Trial:  Our Gear on Amazon:    FOLLOW US ELSEWHERE ---------------------------------------------------   Twitter:  Instagram:  Facebook:     FOLLOW OUR OTHER CHANNELS ---------------------------------------------------   Linus Tech Tips:  Mac Address:  Techquickie:  ShortCircuit:  LMG Clips:  Channel Super Fun:  They're Just Movies podcast:
transcript: - Tech news (beep). (beatboxing comedically) That's the intro. Now that the metaverse is definitely a thing, and not just a buzzword being used inappropriately everywhere, Apple is getting serious about it's long-rumored AR headset. Renowned Apple leaker and rumormonger, Ming-Chi Kuo, says Apple will launch the device in the fourth quarter of 2022, with two processors, a lower end chip to handle sensor data and another one with the same level of computing power as M1. This is gonna be like having a Mac mini strapped to your face? - [Behind Camera] The Macoverse. - (laughs) The Maculous. Immaculate inception. Kuo says to expect a headset with 4K OLED displays for each eye, made by Sony, and the ability to operate untethered, not from the app store, though, (laughs) from an iPhone or Mac. Zuckerberg won't even know what hit him. But, maybe it won't hit him though 'cause he's so good with the arms up. He's ready. He was like, (grunting loudly). (laughs) You know what I'm talking about, though? - [Behind Camera] I don't know, I can imagine. - [Riley] No, it's from the Meta... - [Behind Camera] Okay. - It's from the Meta thing. It's a meme. While America struggles with what to do about big tech's growing power, other nations are makin' moves. Italy is the latest country to take a shot at the oligarchs, announcing around 10 million Euro fines for both Apple and Google, for neglecting to inform users about how their personal data is being collected and used. - [Behind Camera] What's the matter you? - Aw, come on! - [Behind Camera] Capiche? - This is what we think of as Italians. That's like neglecting to boil the water before you put the pasta in. - [Behind Camera] A little olive oil in there. - A little salt. (laughs) Both companies are appealing the fines, even though 10 million is a drop in the bucket compared to the tens of billions of dollars in revenue the companies have made so far this year. And this is actually the second round of fines Italy has issued this week, slapping Apple and Amazon with a combined $230 million fine a few days ago for collusion regarding restrictions on sales of used Apple products. - [Behind Camera] Ciao. - (laughs) Fines, which are also being appealed, but I doubt they're gonna get anywhere. Have you tried arguing with an Italian person? It's impossible. (laughs) And SpaceX successfully launched NASA's Double Asteroid Redirection Test, or DART mission, this week, aboard a Falcon 9 rocket. As it's name implies, the mission will see a spacecraft deliberately smash into an asteroid to see whether we could redirect one on a collision course with Earth. Space garbage! (laughs) Space garbage. Meet space garbage. (laughs) His boy, Elon. All right. Unfortunately, there's no nuclear weapons or Bruce Willises involved in this mission. Grimes, his wife. (laughs) And the asteroid is actually two orbiting bodies, the larger, Didymos, and the smaller, Dimorphos, which are about to be forcefully broken up even though they did nothing wrong. But, NASA's also undertaking a less violent mission on the surface of Mars, using a seismograph set up by the InSight lander to image the first few hundred meters under the planet's surface. Although, if we happen to cross paths with the martian mole people, things might get ugly. Because they're- Have you seen them? They're just, I can't look... They're real. - [Behind Camera] Mole people. - (laughs) What? You're just like the musical accompaniment. Wardrobe change! Now, it's time for Quick Bits brought to you by NZXT's BLD system, which makes getting a custom-built PC as easy as ordering food. But, it's like the good way, where you can customize and add extra mayo, but hold the jalapenos 'cause (coughs) too spicy. Simply set your budget, see how your PC will perform in your favorite games, and let BLD take care of the rest. Because their recommendation engine provides benchmark data guaranteed to be within 10% accuracy. There's transparent pricing, a flat $99 assembly fee, and everything's covered under one warranty plan with NZXT's excellent customer support. Orders are built and shipped within 48 business hours. And it's even available in Australia now, too! So, check out NZXT's BLD system today, at the link below. Quick Bits! - [Behind Camera] Gotta have 'em! - Gotta eat 'em. - [Behind Camera] Can't live without 'em. - Num-nums. - [Behind Camera] Careful when you poop 'em. - (laughs) What? The good news for Linux gamers just keeps on coming. Valve has added support for Nvidia's DLSS to it's latest Proton build, which will allow the tech to work in games that support it. Unfortunately, Valve's own Steam deck won't receive any benefit from this, as it runs on an AMD processor. But, the deck will support Team Red's own FSR sharpening method when it launches next year. So, let's just celebrate the fact that gaming on Linux is more of an option than ever, especially if you don't mind troubleshooting for a few days beforehand. - [Behind Camera] Let's game! (imitating whipping sound) - The UK has introduced a bill that would ban the use of default passwords on smart home devices. We're talking real dumb dumb stuff like, "Password, Admin, 1-2-3-4-5." - [Behind Camera] Hey, that's mine! - (laughs) You should have tried the best one, "Password1." Default passwords can make things super easy for attackers, like the ones that stole data from a casino in 2017 by accessing an interconnected fish tank. (laughs) Were the fish in on it? We may never know. - [Behind Camera] That's fishy. - They were sadly flushed without a trial. Nvidia has made the image-generating AI behind it's Canvas software even better. Now, you don't even have to draw something for the algorithm to transform it into a realistic landscape, you can just type some words and the machine will create something that looks straight out of a stock photo library. Unfortunately, you can't type just anything in there, as the system was trained on 10 million images of landscapes only! - [Behind Camera] No cheese? - No! So, whatever gross thing you're thinking of right now, will have to stay locked up in that messed up head of yours, man. Seriously, you should get some help. Cheese in that scenario? - [Behind Camera] Still life? Classic. (giggling happily) - Microsoft's backwards compatibility program for old Xbox games has been awesome, especially since many titles have benefited from the company's FPS boost technology. But now, Xbox's Jason Ronald- - [Behind Camera] Known as J-Ro. - (laughs) By you. Has said further rollout of FPS boost is on hiatus, as his team is starting to find limitations in their current technique. Which sucks. But, it's also surprising that Microsoft would just admit they're having trouble with something. That's that's big of them. This kinda feels like the old days, right down to the forcing people to use their browser. And French car maker, Renault, has shown off a quad rotor flying version of it's classic Renault 4 hatchback, called the AIR4. - [Behind Camera] Sued by Apple. - (laughs) Gotcha! The company said, "It's designed for the roads of the future that are visualized to be in the air." (talking quietly behind camera) (laughs) That's what they meant to say. Which I'm guessing is an idea based off of "Back to the Future II"? Because, roads in the... That's not... Anyways, the AIR4 is powered by 22,000 Ah power batteries. But, that doesn't matter 'cause you can't buy this thing. It's just cool, just look at it. This is- That's all you're supposed to- There's no analysis here, okay? It's just, "Oh! Couldn't it nice!" - [Behind Camera] "Would you look at that!" - "Ah! It's a flying car!" - [Behind Camera] "Just look at it!" - (moaning comedically) (laughs) What's not nice is that this episode has to end. Come back on Monday for more tech news, and I'll show you all my Black Friday purchases. - [Behind Camera] 22,000 million Ah batteries. - (laughs) A thousand of them individually. Just kidding, I didn't buy anything. Minimalism.
transcript_entity_values: the tens of billions of dollars
